A small essay on imaginary landscapes, works on paper, and Alastor by Percy Bysshe Shelley.[1]

‚ÄúWhen early youth had past, he left
His cold fireside and alienated home

Alastor!

A character encircled by the natural world, Alastor sets out in search of meaning across torn landscapes borne with significance. Mythical places known only to Shelley (whose short life was spent between England, Switzerland, and Italy) from literature and his own fanciful romantic dreams.

The landscape changes quickly and suddenly. From deserts of the cradle of civilization to the splendiferous ranges of the Caucasus. The landscape attains human qualities, emotions and sensations while expressing a magnificent celestial magic. The sublimity of vastness and eternity roots itself in the encounter of the everyday. It is not a real element of nature but one that emerges entirely out of the imaginary.

Mirela Moscu paints characters in dark natures who at times, encounter strange animals. A folkloric interpretation harking to the mysterious events we may encounter in any wooded knoll brought to life by secret inhabitants. Charlotte Herzig‚Äôs dancing forms are abstractions of plantlife as an ode to modernism. Arranged in composed and arithmetic spaces, the forms break logic with their inherent organicity. Estanis Comella collects moments through photography and drawings. Walking through urban peripheries, the objects and weeds that are found amid the marginal architecture creates its own imaginary of techno and punk subcultures with their own romanticism and necessity of forgotten expanses.

Changing landscape creates the narrative and drives the protagonist through. Whether an eerie corner, an arboreous copse, or a disembodied monstera deliciosa ‚Äì human cultural associations and symbols provide a mental state for its disambiguation. The landscape describes the physical and mental conditions of the protagonist through his journey.

All of this imaginary of human fancy recorded on the page (bl√§tter, German: leaves) as record of human invention. The paper itself adds pigments to the vegetal ligaments of those original plants. Works on paper could refer to the exhibited works, to the poem, and the leaves themselves - found along the way in representation.

Organic forms riddled with sentiment, emotion. The lost protagonist encountered in overcrowded vegetation. And the feeling of lightness, a dreamscape. A mutual destiny.

‚ÄúNow upon the jagg√®d hills
It rests, and still as the divided frame
Of the vast meteor sunk, the Poet's blood,
That ever beat in mystic sympathy
With nature's ebb and flow, grew feebler still:‚Äù

[1]Percy Bysshe Shelley (1792-1822), english poet and thinker, author of Alastor or the spirit of solitude.

L‚Äôobra de Natalie Bookchin va comen√ßar a ser coneguda internacionalment en els anys noranta, quan se la va considerar part d‚Äôuna generaci√≥ d‚Äôartistes pioners en l‚Äô√†mbit de la cultura digital que, lluny d‚Äôactituds tecn√≤files, van adoptar una posici√≥ cr√≠tica mitjan√ßant la pr√†ctica del net-artivisme ‚Äìuna combinaci√≥ de xarxa-art-activisme‚Äì davant de la creixent bretxa digital sobre l‚Äôesfera p√∫blica, econ√≤mica i cultural als Estats Units.

A mitjan d√®cada del 2000, inicia una etapa en qu√® els materials derivats d‚Äôinternet i les xarxes socials seran centrals en la seva obra. Hi s√≥n presents des de l‚Äô√∫s d‚Äôimatges fetes per c√†meres web de seguretat desprotegides i accessibles a trav√©s de Google, fins a l‚Äôapropiaci√≥ de v√≠deos de baixa qualitat i resoluci√≥ penjats a YouTube (el fair use o ‚Äú√∫s leg√≠tim‚Äù √©s una forma legal a YouTube que permet reutilitzar materials protegits per drets d‚Äôautor sense el perm√≠s del propietari).

A partir de l‚Äôedici√≥ de centenars de v√≠deos disponibles en l√≠nia, l‚Äôartista construeix un mosaic d‚Äôautoretrats en pantalles m√∫ltiples disposades de manera seriada, que formen complexos paisatges sonors, veus polif√≤niques, cossos coreografiats i representacions m√≤bils.

La videoinstal¬∑laci√≥ multicanal Mass Ornament (2009) √©s el resultat de recombinar desenes de videoblogs que, com si fossin miralls, mostren una s√®rie d‚Äôadolescents solit√†ries que ballen en els seus dormitoris imitant les estrelles del pop. Mitjan√ßant la postproducci√≥ d‚Äôespais, de gestos, de passos i, fins i tot, de preses de c√†mera que repeteixen el mateix patr√≥, Bookchin ens revela una representaci√≥ mecanitzada de la intimitat, on sembla que els desitjos, les relacions i les identitats hagin estat intervinguts per la pantalla.

En produccions posteriors, com Now he‚Äôs out in public and everyone can see (2012-2017), la sincronitzaci√≥ de les imatges dona pas a m√∫ltiples v√≠deos dispersos ca√≤ticament per la pantalla, de manera que creen una cacofonia de rostres i de sons que suggereixen una desconnexi√≥ entre si.Iniciat durant l‚Äôetapa presidencial d‚ÄôObama als Estats Units, Bookchin construeix un nou mosaic de fragments de videoblogs, en els quals persones de diverses proced√®ncies responen, a trav√©s d‚Äôinternet, a les tensions racials que es van intensificar durant aquell per√≠ode. Davant d‚Äôuna esfera p√∫blica controlada pels mitjans de comunicaci√≥ adre√ßats a les classes populars blanques, Bookchin posa en relleu com, en plena √®poca de xarxes socials, els relats fabricats, els rumors i la desinformaci√≥ amb prou feines es distingeixen de la informaci√≥ vera√ß.

En els seus darrers treballs audiovisuals, Natalie Bookchin produeix retrats col¬∑lectius d‚Äôuna multitud activa socialment i pol√≠ticament, formada per singularitats que interpel¬∑len aspectes que avui preocupen la societat nord-americana. Es tracta de persones que, per la seva marginalitat o posici√≥ subalterna, no acostumem a percebre a trav√©s de les nostres finestres cat√≤diques. De nou, Bookchin mostra una pantalla amb m√∫ltiples retrats parlants, encapsulats en els seus propis marcs, que puntualment, com si es tract√©s d‚Äôun cor grec, generen ecos i repeticions que destaquen les experi√®ncies compartides i les semblances i que instiguen vincles inesperats i desconeguts entre si. Davant d‚Äôunes tecnologies de la comunicaci√≥ que tendeixen a desactivar la comprensi√≥ del que √©s com√∫, Bookchin proposa reimaginar-les com a espais des dels quals es pot configurar una noci√≥ diferent del que √©s social i col¬∑lectiu, i apel¬∑lar a la solidaritat i a l‚Äôempatia amb tot el seu potencial pendent de realitzar-se.

‚ÄúSoy extremadamente sensible a mi entorno, creo que √©ste es el motivo por el cual los materiales y las texturas ocupan un lugar central en mi pr√°ctica art√≠stica. Para m√≠ √©sta implicaba rigidez y formalidad y sent√≠ la necesidad inmediata de modificarla. 

A partir de la relaci√≥n hist√≥rica que el barrio de Poble Sec tiene con el agua, he estado pensando en el agua como una fuerza aplacadora, niveladora y renovadora; una fuerza con una superficie amorfa y una profundidad en la que los objetos se suspenden, silencian y desarman. Compr√© un pl√°stico azul transl√∫cido y envolv√≠ la silla con √©l. De inmediato adquiri√≥ una calidad absurda y contorsionada. Haciendo referencia a aquello sint√©tico y algo burdo de los elementos, junto con las huellas de lo real, Turn it into Water es una reflexi√≥n sobre la forma en que navegamos por nuestro entorno construido, as√≠ como sobre las inc√≥gnitas primordiales que permanecen detr√°s de nuestros marcos sociales de referencia.‚Äù  Mia Middleton

*Mia Middleton es una artista multidisciplinaria que actualmente vive en S√≠dney, Australia. Su pr√°ctica explora el flujo dicot√≥mico entre la presencia y el anhelo, la superficie y el vac√≠o, as√≠ como la psico-geograf√≠a de ambientes sint√©ticos y ut√≥picos, rompiendo y redirigiendo las apariencias virtuales y f√≠sicas que los caracterizan. El resultado es una combinaci√≥n de lo dom√©stico y lo fant√°stico, donde las m√∫ltiples espacialidades existen como t√°ndem, y los deseos y los sue√±os se mezclan con revestimientos y fachadas.
Desde que termin√≥ la Licenciatura en Bellas Artes, especializada en fotograf√≠a, en la UNSW Art and Design en 2013, la obra de Mia Middleton ha sido expuesta en espacios tanto de Australia como del extranjero como M Contemporary Gallery, Kudos Gallery, The Museum of Contemporary Art ARTBAR, CICA Museum de Corea y el Festival de Arte Digital de Atenas. En 2011 recibi√≥ el Premio de Fotograf√≠a Canson y en 2016 realiz√≥ un conjunto de performances para el festival de arte de performances Desire Lines de S√≠dney. Recientemente ha comisariado y expuesto en la exposici√≥n colectiva Orbit en la Down Under Space de S√≠dney (setiembre 2017) y ha participado junto a otros 35 artistas en una exposici√≥n colectiva de fotograf√≠a en la Cold Cuts Gallery de S√≠dney (octubre 2017). En 2018 presentar√° una exposici√≥n monogr√°fica en la Blindside Gallery de Melbourne.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm extremely sensitive to my environment, I think thats why materials and textures take centre stage in my practice. The surfaces and objects around us form part of a strategic system of engagement. In my work I find myself harnessing and reshaping these things as a way of exposing and reclaiming them. At Homesession my first act in this vein was to ‚Äòtrap‚Äô the bulky grey office chair that lingered awkwardly in the space. It implied rigidity and formality to me and I felt an immediate need to alter it. 

Triggered by Poble Sec‚Äôs history with water, I had been thinking about water as a placating, levelling and renewing force, one with an amorphous surface and depth which objects become suspended, quietened and disarmed in. I bought some translucent blue PVC and wrapped the chair in it and it immediately took on an absurd and contorted quality. Following this I continued to explore the ethereality of water as a means to connect with the infinite and the cosmic, as well as humanity‚Äôs inevitable need to cover, mould, confine and replicate natural forms. Using somewhat crude synthetic allusions to the elements, coupled with traces of the real thing, Turn it into Water is a rumination on the way we navigate our built environment, and the primal unknowns which linger behind our social frames of reference.‚Äù   Mia Middleton

*Mia Middleton is a multi-disciplinary artist currently based in Sydney, Australia. Her practice explores the dichotomous flux between presence and longing, surface and void. In particular, she focuses on the psycho-geography of synthetic and utopic environments by breaking apart and re-purposing the virtual and physical veneers that typify them. The result is a conflation of the domestic and the fantastic, where multiple spatialities exist in tandem, and desires and dreams commingle with coverings and facades. Since completing a Bachelor of Fine Arts (Honours) in photo-media at UNSW Art and Design in 2013, Mia‚Äôs work has exhibited at galleries both nationally and abroad, including M Contemporary Gallery, Kudos Gallery, The Museum of Contemporary Art ARTBAR, CICA Museum, Korea and the Athens Digital Arts Festival. In 2011, she was the recipient of the Canson Photography Prize and in 2016 she completed a suite of performances for Sydney based performance art festival Desire Lines. In September 2017 Mia Middleton curated and exhibited in the three-person exhibition Orbit at Down Under Space, Sydney, and in October she exhibited alongside 35 others in a survey of expanded photographic works at Cold Cuts Gallery, Sydney. In 2018 Mia will be traveling and presenting a solo exhibition at Blindside Gallery in Melbourne.
